moves.3. f4: The usual, aggressive line. 2. f4 immediately is well met with 2....d5, hence 2. Nc3 first.
moves.3... g6: I fianchetto, aiming for control of the d4 square.
moves.5... Nd4: Attacking his bishop and not allowing the doubling of my pawns.
moves.10. Qe1: Perhaps played with the idea of Qe1-h4 should I castle king side.
moves.13. f5: I can't take three times on f5 without losing a piece because of the half-pin on the e file.
moves.14. g4: I think this is a mistake, just losing a pawn. I was expecting 14. Nh4.
moves.17... d5: Thematic central break to distract from attempted king-side attack.
moves.18. Nef5: Threatening to take off my powerful Bg7
moves.23. Bf4: He develops his bishop at last.
moves.30... c3:
Onward again! "30...c3, 31.Rc7! 
It seems that 30...c3 wasn't such a good idea. Maybe 30...h5 would have been safer." archduke_piccolo
moves.31. Re7: Oops! I had completely missed this move.
moves.32. Be5: He takes control of the important diagonal.
moves.32... h6: Played to give my king a flight square.
moves.33. Rdd7: He doubles on the 7th rank, threatening mate.
moves.35. Kh3: More or less forced. I am now protecting g7, so there is no mate threat.
moves.37. Bb2:
Bishop drops back. Now if I queen, he just takes, and I can't take back as he has mate in two. "37.Bb2 (I think - from memory - 37.Rdg7ch at once would have secured the draw) 
37... Bd4!! 
ensures the pawn will promote as Black has to prevent the mate." archduke_piccolo
moves.40. f7: his own advanced pawn is powerful too!
moves.41. Rg8+: He checks, from both rook and bishop, my reply is forced.
moves.42... Kh8:
Forced again. Draw by perpetual check. "Fantastic game, though! I haven't looked closely into the earlier part of the game, but I like the strategic dichotomy of White's K-side attack vs Black's on the Q-side, especially as it persists even into the 2R + B late middle game. (Incidentally, I don't call the late play end games unless and until the number of pieces have been reduced to two or fewer.) 

Cheers, 
Ion" (archduke_piccolo) Many thanks for reading. Please rate this annotation on the start system and leave a comment or two to let me know how I am doing. Until next time dear reader!

players: Philip AM Zabrocki (ECF182) vs. Charles L Higgie (ECF180)
opening: Sicilian (B23), Grand Prix attack, Schofman variation
